title: Office values will hold even as rental growth slows, says Harrison
text:
Vacancy rates are below 4 per cent in both Sydney and Melbourne, around half the level at which the market is generally seen as being in equilibrium and capable of generating growth in line with inflation.

Additionally, capitalisation rates – an industry equivalent to investment yields – are still catching up with the fall in bond yields globally as the worldwide low-yield environment drives investment into real assets, including property.

"I don't see cap rates softening. If anything, based on current sales evidence, particularly in office and industrial markets, cap rates are going to continue to compress," Mr Harrison said.

The $750 million tower at 130 Lonsdale Street has already been fully leased well before its expected completion in mid-2020.

The tower at 130 Lonsdale Street is due to be completed in mid-2020.

AustralianSuper is joining other pension funds, including Cbus and Telstra Super, Vanguard and the Australian Financial Complaints Authority in a high-powered, high-rise hub for fund managers at the east end of the CBD. Leavening the tenancy mix is the Uniting Church, which holds the freehold for the Lonsdale Street site.

The 60,000sq m building, held in the unlisted Charter Hall Prime Office Fund, is one of three towers within a larger precinct along Lonsdale Street controlled by Charter Hall, on either side of the historic bluestone Wesley Unity Church.

Advertisement

Net face rents in the new building have been struck at between about $550 and the low $600 range. That is half the amount tenants are paying in comparable buildings in Sydney, a point noted by Mr Harrison at the topping out event attended byVictorian Treasurer Tim Pallas.

Markets to weaken

Moody's, in its analysis of the listed property trusts' annual earnings, forecast the performance of the Sydney and Melbourne markets to moderate.

"We expect conditions will weaken post-2020 on a new wave of supply, a weaker macroeconomic backdrop and lower business confidence," the ratings agency reported Wednesday. It noted that net operating income growth had increased for office landlords and that cap rates would "remain supportive and are likely to tighten further".

Last week JPMorgan analysts cautioned that softening outlook for office rent growth was likely to impact cap rates.
description: Office rents in the booming Sydney and Melbourne markets are finally set to ease back from double-digit growth, but the Charter Hall MD remains bullish.
